name: geothermal power plant construction, Hot-Dry-Rock | geothermal power plant, Hot-Dry-Rock | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4522/documentation

Enhanced geothermal systems (EGS), also known as Hot-Dry-Rock (HDR) systems, enable the exploration of the Earth’s interior heat outside known geothermal provinces. EGS are exploited with artificial stimulation of tight rock formations by hydraulic fracturing in order to create an underground heat exchanger. Fluid is circulated in a closed circle during operation, whereby reservoir pressures and fluid throughputs are managed by balanced production and injection rates in multiple well array.It is assumed for this dataset that HDR power plants represent all binary cycle geothermal power plants existing. According to (Ruggero, B. 2010. Geothermal Power Generation in the World. 2005-2010 Update Report. Proceedings World Geothermal Congress 2010; Bali, Indonesia, 25-29 April 2010), the binary cycle type represents 9% of capacity installed worldwide.;;The plant modelled in this dataset consists out of three deep boreholes with depths between 5000 m and 6000 m. One of them is used as the injection well for the cold fluid leaving the generation unit, the other two as production wells, which provide the hot fluid, heated up within the hot rock formation. One test drilling of 2000m depth for exploration (rock, temperature gradient, aquifers, etc.) is conducted. Then, the injection and the production wells are drilled. The injection well is used for the stimulation of the rock (fracturing): A mixture of water and sand is pressed down with high pressure in order to enlarge the present fractures in the rock and to make it more permeable. During the operation of the power plant, water will pass through this permeable (hot) rock, be heated and pumped through the production well to the ORC unit.;;A temperature gradient of 35-40°C per kilometer depth can be assumed. An Organic Rankine Cycle unit with binary cycle and a capacity of 3MWel is used for electricity generation. Further key components of the plant are the underground chromium steel pipes between the injection wells and the generation unit and for water supply. A lifetime of 20 years is assumed for the power plant.;;Source of the image: Geothermal Explorers Ltd. 2011. Project Deep Heat Mining Basel. http://www.geothermal.ch; visited January 2011.;

Construction of a geothermal Hot-Dry-Rock plant.

This activity ends with the geothermal power plant constructed and ready for electricity production.

 Energy use for pumping is directly taken from the energy produced at the ORC unit. 

This dataset doesn't include most of the dismantling activities. It does not include motor vehicles for internal transport and minor maintenance items. It does not include further buildings for administration or maintenance. The chromium steel pipes usually remain in the ground after use. No outputs to the environment (leaching) has been considered.
category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: - Rock temperature in a depth of 5500m: ca. 230°C.;- ORC unit: 3MWel, 30MWth, binary cycle. No use of the thermal capacity.;- Flow rate: 224 m3/h;- Land required: 7500m2;

flow.name: geothermal power plant, Hot-Dry-Rock
flow.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Used for stimulation as fracture propping agent (proppant). After drilling of the boreholes, the injection well is used for the stimulation of the rock (fracturing): A mixture of water and sand is pressed down with high pressure in order to enlarge the present fractures in the rock and to make it more permeable. During the operation of the power plant, water will pass through this permeable (hot) rock, be heated and pumped to the ORC unit in the production well.

Rogge (2004) assumes 60t of sand per well.

exchanges.description:
Literature value/estimated value. Used for rising pipes in the production well and the pump.

Rogge (2004) assumes 7.3t of steel for these elements per production well.

exchanges.description: Estimated value/measured value. This value is taken from a projected geothermal plant in Switzerland. It includes land use of the well and of the whole power plant area, including buildings etc. It is estimated that the drillings are made greenfield.

Literature value. Used for stimulation as fracture propping agent (proppant). After drilling of the boreholes, the injection well is used for the stimulation of the rock (fracturing): A mixture of water and sand is pressed down with high pressure in order to enlarge the present fractures in the rock and to make it more permeable. During the operation of the power plant, water will pass through this permeable (hot) rock, be heated and pumped to the ORC unit in the production well.

Rogge (2004) assumes 60t of sand per well.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. The plant modelled in this dataset consists out of three deep boreholes with depths of about 5500 m and, as the holes are not totally straight,  a total length of about 6000m. One of them is used as the injection well for the cold fluid leaving the generation unit, the other two as production wells, which provide the hot fluid, heated up within the hot rock formation. One test drilling of 2000m depth is assumed, but with a smaller diameter than for the production and injection wells, therefore operating expenses should be smaller. A reduction of 50% is arbitrarily assumed.

exchanges.description:
Literature value. These are the fluid pipes for the connection of the production wells with the ORC unit and back into the injection well again. Data from (Rogge 2004) for an installed capacity of 1 MWel and a length of pipes of 1600 m are directly used for the modelled plant. The pipes are piped underground. 

If the working temperature of the water is lower than 90°C, there could also be used plastic pipes.
